title:
Laser-Driven Proton-Only Acceleration in a Multicomponent
  Near-Critical-Density Plasma
authors:
Y. Sakawa, H. Ishihara, S. N. Ryazantsev, M. A. Alkhimova, R. Kumar,
  O. Kuramoto, Y. Matsumoto, M. Ota, S. Egashira, Y. Nakagawa, T. Minami, K.
  Sakai, T. Taguchi, H. Habara, Y. Kuramitsu, A. Morace, Y. Abe, Y. Arikawa, S.
  Fujioka, M. Kanasaki, T. Asai, T. Morita, Y. Fukuda, S. Pikuz, T. Pikuz, Y.
  Ohira, L. N. K. Doehl, N. Woolsey, and T. Sano
abstract:
An experimental investigation of collisionless shock ion acceleration is
presented using a multicomponent plasma and a high-intensity picosecond
duration laser pulse. Protons are the only accelerated ions when a
near-critical-density plasma is driven by a laser with a modest normalized
vector potential. The results of particle-in-cell simulations imply that
collisionless shock may accelerate protons alone selectively, which can be an
important tool for understanding the physics of inaccessible collisionless
shocks in space and astrophysical plasma.
